line.text: Can’t… see.
What the hell, am I blind now?
All right, calm down. Never heard of mag-pulse exposure making people lose their eyesight.
Badge-wielding psychos. Shorting out a guy’s implants before they’ve even charged him with anything? What kind of…
Okay, focus. It can’t just be dark in here. I should be seeing error messages—hell, a command prompt, at least. Something.
What if I’m only “snowblind,” and my optic implants are projecting a static image onto my retinas?
But then why aren’t they disabled entirely? The EMBlazers obviously worked—my wetware is toast.
How am I supposed to disable my optics without a functioning command interface? I can’t even… Everything’s…
Okay wait wait wait.
That minicomputer thing. It only runs UL/M, but it’s shielded, right? Never thought I’d ever actually—
Uh. Hey… minicomp? Command: wake.
MINICOMPUTER Status: BOOTING
Loading…
MINICOMPUTER Status: READY
Oh thank God.
Minicomp: Command queue, killall brace tick star dot wetware tick comma dash A unbrace. Execute.
Executing…
WETWARE PROCESSES STOPPED
Right. Jail.
Why am I even in custody, though? Has to be some sort of local crackdown. Even the craziest jobs I’ve done wouldn’t warrant that level of SWAT response.
Minicomp: new VISOR overlay, type: to-do list. I’ll update it as I go.
Let’s have a look around.
Can’t… see.
What the hell?
Okay, this is bad.
Maybe I’m just…
Have I gone blind, or something?
Maybe it’s just really dark in here.
Maybe my eye implants are malfunctioning?
All right, all right, calm down. Never heard of mag-pulse exposure making people lose their eyesight.
Then again, who knows? Some of my wetware’s plugged all the way into the cerebral cortex. A few fried neurons, and…
No. There’s got to be another explanation.
Are the cops putting hackers into isolation chambers now? Wouldn’t put it past ’em.
My night vision should’ve flipped on automatically, but I guess we can assume the EMBlazers did their job.
Badge-wielding psychos. Shorting out a guy’s implants before they’ve even charged him with anything? What kind of…
Okay, focus. It can’t just be dark in here. I should be seeing error messages—hell, a command prompt, at least. Something.
What did the cops do to me?
So suppose I’m only snowblind: my optic implants are projecting a static image onto my retinas.
But then why aren’t they disabled entirely? This makes no sense! Shouldn’t I be—
Just… Start over. Cops blast you with an EMP. Wetware is mostly solid-state, can’t be offlined by an induced current.
The relays might overload, but… Oh, no. Oh… no.
Tower-of-Babel scenario. Worse than offline. Headgear’s crashed but still running, systems can’t talk to each other.
How am I supposed to disable my optics without a functioning command interface? I can’t even… Everything’s…
Okay wait wait wait.
The Matryoshka. That should—I mean, this is what it’s for, right?
Uh. Hey, minicomp. Wake up.
MINICOMPUTER Status: BOOTING
Loading…
MINICOMPUTER Status: READY
Oh thank God.
Minicomp: Command queue, killall brace tick star dot wetware tick comma dash A unbrace. Execute.
Executing…
WETWARE PROCESSES STOPPED
Right. Jail.
Why am I even in custody, though? Has to be some sort of local crackdown. Even the craziest jobs I’ve done wouldn’t warrant that level of SWAT response.
Better have a look around, I guess.
Minicomp: new VISOR overlay, type: to-do list. I’ll update it as I go.
That guy looks mean. Better not bother him without a good reason.
Hey.
Hey!
I’m pretty sure I have the right to a phone call.
Shut up and sit still. You’ll get your call when I’m done here.
Typical. Screw this guy.
So, uh…
All right. Let’s see if I can score a visit to that videophone. Time to turn on the charm…
This is getting me nowhere. There’s gotta be something in this room I can use to get on this guy’s good side.
Computer troubles?
You’re holding me here illegally.
I demand to talk to a lawyer.
Do you have some kind of grudge against hackers?
Nothing. Never mind.
Whoa. That phone looks ancient.
Probably has a data connection, though. Hmm.
This is sad. You’ve got your SWAT guys running around with military-grade EMBlazers, but your beat cops are stuck using data-phones from 30 years ago?
Guess I’m not the only one trapped in the stone age, here.
Still. That thing’s gotta have a data connection.
I bet I could crack my way into it… somehow… assuming I ever get my phone call.
I guess I should go offer to help the guard with that Soviet-era computer of his…
That crappy old phone is probably the only chance I have of connecting to the grids.
I gotta get that guard to let me have my phone call.
Oh man, a Northstar-80? Do those even have color screens?
No wonder the guard looks so pissed off. I’d go nuts if I had to work on a relic like that.
Maybe the guy’ll let me have my phone call if I help him out. Worth a shot. I guess.
Anyway. Kinda doubt the guy’s gonna let me hang out at his desk and take his computer for a spin.
Looks like the guard’s still losing his battle of wits with that old Northstar-80.
S’pose I should give him a hand.
If you’re having trouble with that machine, I can probably help. I know a lot about computers.
Really? I know a lot about beating detainees unconscious.
Why am I in here? I know my rights. You can’t detain me without charges. It’s the Fifth Amendment.
Fourteenth Amendment.
I… huh?
Fifth Amendment is only for the feds. Don’t worry, you’ve been charged with plenty.
Oh. Good.
All right, that’s it, I’m invoking my right to an attorney.
No one’s questioning you.
But—
Is this a personal thing, or do you just have a problem with hackers in general?
I have a problem with overprivileged punks running wild on the grids like the laws don’t apply to them. Spying, scamming. Stealing anything that isn’t bolted down.
Leaving normal folks with whatever gimped systems are left once you’re all done joyriding and vandalizing.
So yeah. I have a problem with hackers.
Well… okay, but… I mean, not all hackers are like that.
I mean, some of them are criminals, sure, but most are motivated by curiosity more than anything else.
There are even white-hat hackers, the ones who do security testing and work to make sure the grids are—
Kid, anyone that gets his ass dragged in here by a SWAT team at three in the morning ain’t the good kind of hacker. You hear what I’m saying?
Yeah. I hear you.
But I stand by what I said. Let me help you get your report printed.
No deal.
I’m not dealing. I’ll help you print your report. That’s all.
Kid, I wasn’t born yesterday.
No really. I want to help.
Look, I’ve got nothing to do in here, and I like figuring stuff out. Okay?
If you think you can fix it yourself, then…
Suit yourself. If you’d rather waste your night swearing at a printer, be my guest.
Nice one. We’ll see how far that attitude gets you at Riker’s.
Right. Well, until then, you’ve got a computer expert sitting ten feet away. Might as well make the most of it.
If you think I’d let you within spitting range of this keyboard…
No, no no. I’m not going to be hacking your machine. You are.
Excuse me?
Look, just read me whatever error message you see on your screen.
Fine. It says “ERROR -84”.
Huh. That’s not very informative. Okay, let me think.
I should have a bunch of old computer manuals in wetRAM, but without knowing which operating system and hardware we’re talking about, they won’t do me much good.
So, what kind of system have you got there?
It says “Vidtron 880” on it.
Er, well, that’s just the monitor. Your systems are probably running in a thin-client config, which means the actual mainframe is in a server room somewhere. Do you know if—
No.
Just tell me if the drivers are SMC-compatible, that would… Wait— you guys aren’t using paravirtualization, are you?
You know what? Forget it. Forget I said anything about computers.
Aw, c’mon.
Jeez. How can you sit at a terminal all day and not know anything about computers?
Not a lot to go on. Might as well pull up those manuals and see what I can figure out.
Hey minicomp. Bring up the nexus, would you?
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
“Data Center”? Man. Everybody’s gotta have an important-looking door that says “Data Center” nowadays.
That terminal screen’s not even showing anything relevant. Looks like it’s just a dump of the cache history as it gets purged. What a sham…
Wait, what language is that? Looks vaguely like XALGO, but with Z.shell-style expressions. Hmm.
Some sort of corporate variant, maybe? Let’s go take another look at those printer manuals.
Whatever. I’ll be sure to post all about it on HackOps later. Right now I gotta find a way outta here.
Holy cow, is that a printer? It’s the size of a vending machine!
Not sure why it bugs me so much that these guys are clearing the streets with CROW mechs and razorade, then coming back and filling out their paperwork on papyrus…
I guess I just expected better of the iron fist of the police state.
All right, I think that gives me enough to go on. Let’s pull up the Nexus, take another look at those manuals.
So let’s see… No direct cable connection to the terminal, which means it’s a shared printer. There’s probably a data center around here.
One node. Jesus. There should be a whole galaxy in here.
Right. Let’s get to work.
“About.” I’m curious to see how much of the World Grid you can visualize on 64K of RAM.
A Nexus is [tedious backstory stuff goes here], etc.
“Opening and Closing.” Ugh, only one node open at a time?
The user can interact with a Nexus node in several different ways.
[Blah blah click once to highlight a Nexus node; Double-click to connect, etc.]
“Navigating.” I’m gonna be scrubbing through a ton of info.
[Boring stuff about servers, connection security and attenuation limits goes here.]
Dismiss helpscreen.
Yeah, that’s about what I figured. I got my whole archive of computer manuals in here, but no way to know which one’s got the answers to this “ERROR -38” thing.
The guard is running some sort of Fieldbus terminal, so that eliminates anything from the last decade or so. Cable port looked like an X.27, which means… nothing, really.
All right, let’s see what we’ve got.
Still not enough to go on. I gotta look around the precinct some more, find some detail that I missed.
Not enough. There must be something in the precinct I’ve missed.
Minicomp, disengage the Nexus.
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
That cache dump the Data Center monitor was running… The code seemed like some sort of corporate XALGO. That narrows things down a bit.
But software isn’t enough. I need more insight on the hardware this office is running.
Minicomp, disengage the Nexus.
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
Since the printer isn’t connected to the terminal, that means there’s a print server in a data center somewhere. That eliminates any systems that only support client-side printing.
It’s a start. But I gotta find out more about that data center.
Minicomp, disengage the Nexus.
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
Thin-client system, more than ten years old, runs some flavor of XALGO, and supports print serving.
Minicomp, search printer reset commands for systems matching the three criteria I just listed.
One match: “Error -84. Print queue not responding.”
Well, that’s not too bad. Just gotta send a reboot command to the printer, then. Right, time to go talk to that guard.
Minicomp, disengage the Nexus.
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
All right, let’s see what the manual says about… Ah. Error -84. “Print queue not responding.”
Well that’s not too bad. Just gotta send a reboot command to the printer, then. Right, time to go talk to that guard.
Minicomp, disengage the Nexus.
Command not understood. Loading Nexus helpscreen…
Great! That oughtta do it. If I can get the guard to type that letter-for-letter, it should reset his password back to “admin,” which is the default.
Just hope he goes for it.
Okay, I think I can help you with that “Error 84” thing. Can you open up the console and try sending a reboot command?
I have no idea what you just said.
Right. Uh, on most computers you hit Alt-tilde to pull up the console.
Alt what?
The… squiggle mark. It’s paired with the backtick key, usually below Esc or to the left of Return.
So why don’t you just call it the squiggle key?
Okay. Found it.
My screen just went black. Nice work, kid.
It’s not completely black. There should be a prompt in the top left corner, with a cursor next to it. Right?
It just says “USR00882>_”.
I’m guessing that means you’re user 882. All right, so, do you know the reset command for this server?
What do you think?
Just asking. Try typing * SYSTEM.PQUEUE:/STOP;START -V.
Nothing’s happening.
…And hit “Enter.”
I get a bunch of scrolling gibberish on my screen.
Good, that means the server is restarting. Hopefully. Once it’s done, it should re-launch the queue controller, and you’ll be able to print your report.
How long’s that gonna take?
The reboot shouldn’t take more than a few minutes. Let me know when the gibberish stops scrolling.
Fine.
All right, this is it. I’ve only got one shot at hacking that gridphone. One shot…
…That’s assuming I can conjure up some sort of connection to the grids using nothing but a hacked phone.
Let’s go look at that phone again. I need a solid plan for this.
Okay, I think I can help you with that “Error 84” thing. I think it means you’re out of paper.
What do you think I am, stupid? There’s plenty of paper in there.
Uh, maybe try opening the tray and closing it again?
Thanks for nothing, kid.
Crap, I must’ve pulled the wrong manual. I’d better go look over my notes again.
All right, that gibberish on your screen? There’s a command to get rid of it and go back to your regular screen.
I’m waiting.
It’s a long command, though. You’ll have to type it exactly as I say, otherwise it won’t work.
Got it. Get on with it.
Okay, type the following: sw.52.20/ esetradm/+sc/inpa/+db/s/+gn.77+wp.44/ * /+sw/ult,efa/
Jeez. Okay. Hold on.
No change. Gibberish is still there.
…And hit “Enter.”
Okay. Good. And I think the report is done printing.
So… does that mean I can have my phone call?
Whatever. I guess.
But after that, I don’t wanna hear another peep outta you. Understood?
Understood. Thanks.
Let’s go.
Did the password reset even work? No way to know! So stressed out… Kind of a rush, though. Hope I can type, my hands are shaking so much.
Here goes nothing…
Don’t bother me if you’re not gonna help.
Can’t talk to the guard yet. Not until I have a plan for what I’m gonna do with that phone.
Okay. Think. The phone has a grid connection. I don’t. How do we fix this?
Maybe I could use the phone to…
…tap into the police data room?
…piggyback onto its grid connection?
…create a distraction?
…electrocute the guard?
Time for a break. Let’s do this later.
It would be really great if I could hack into that data center. I could spend the night wiping out my entire police dossier. Hell, why stop there?
Whoa, dial it back. Plenty of time for mad schemes later. The real question is, could I get in there?
The gridphone’s only set up to make phone calls and provide basic directory functions. To get access to the data center, I’d have to…
…reroute the wiring?
…telnet into the data room?
…unlock the door and run inside?
Back up. These are all terrible ideas.
The phone’s already got a connection. Could I share it, somehow? Configure the phone to act as a router?
Not sure about this one. The phone just doesn’t have the hardware to distribute its own grid connection. Unless I…
…plug in a really long cable?
…use my wetware as a router?
…share the connection from somewhere else?
Nah, don’t think any of these’ll work.
The phone’s already got a connection. Could I share it, somehow? Configure the phone to act as a router?
Not sure about this one. The phone just doesn’t have the hardware to distribute its own grid connection. Unless I…
…plug in a really long cable?
…use my wetware as a router?
…share the connection from somewhere else?
Nah, don’t think any of these’ll work.
Could I use the phone to create a diversion? Shake off the guard and slip away?
I could set off a station-wide fire alarm, or better yet—hack the phone so it catches fire!
Except… The timing doesn’t work in my favor. I could fake a full-on nuclear strike warning, but end up stuck back in my cell before I could take advantage of the confusion.
Distraction’s no good. I can’t take the chance that I’ll be locked up when it takes effect. Back to the drawing board.
I could, like, short-circuit one of the capacitors in the phone, then get the guard to touch a bare wire, so that…
Yeah, I don’t think assaulting a cop is the smartest way to get myself out of jail.
Not to mention that I’m just as likely to electrocute myself by accident. Moving on.
What if I physically re-wired the cables? Maybe I could give my wetware direct access the police data room. That’d be pretty sweet.
‘Course, I’m making a lot of assumptions, here. The data-room cabling is probably isolated from the phone lines. And my wetware is barely functional as it is.
Even if I pulled it off somehow, I’d only have a connection for the duration of the phone call. Once I went back to my cell, I’d be just as offline as before.
I need more than just a few minutes of grid access. I need to restore my wetware’s connection to the outside world. But how?
…use an outside connection?
…use the phone’s connection?
…use the guard’s connection?
Nope, none of these.
I could use the phone interface to telnet into the data room, wipe out all my records. Then just wait it out in my cell until tomorrow morning, and then…
Then what? They just let me go free? The cops obviously rely on pen and paper around here. I could clean out their whole database and they might not even notice!
Plus, I question my ability to hack through data-room security protocols on a 15-year-old phone with a numeric keypad.
A job like that, you’d want a cluster of xFLOP rigs, packed to the brim with cryptkits. Even then…
No. Unworkable.
Use the phone to spring the data-room door, bolt through and barricade myself inside. The damage I could wreak would be epic. The Hack.Ops community would worship me!
Er, of course, I’d still be trapped in the police station. And charged with, like, a million counts of malicious hacking.
But the sheer audacity of it! Hackers would be naming their workstations after me!
Stop. I’m supposed to be trying to get myself out of jail, not further in.
Maybe I could just jack directly into to the phone with a cable?
Yeah, that’s… I’m pretty sure the guard would notice a twelve-meter cable sticking out of my head.
Also, I don’t actually have a twelve-meter cable.
So…
My wetware might be able to distribute the phone’s connection. It’s actually a pretty cool idea, but…
But it requires a partner. One person sets up their wetware to act as an ad-hoc router, while the other person tunnels in.
And I don’t have a partner.
So that’s that.
The phone’s just a node on the network. It’s not really the device I want to tap into. It’s the grid.
So how do I get into that network? It’s completely cable-based, no RAIN.
Although, most corporate network routers have built-in RAIN these days, it’s just disabled for security reasons. And rightly so—I’d be able to crack it in minutes.
Could I use the phone to enable intra-office RAIN? It’d be perfect. I’d have unlimited grid access, even inside my cell. But to access the office network settings, I’d have to…
…log in as the guard?
…try to scam someone in network security?
Hmm. Better rethink this.
Okay, so let’s say I log into the phone using the guard’s credentials, which incidentally I don’t have, but let’s say I do.
I drop out of the telephone interface into kiosk mode, navigate my way to the office network settings, enable RAIN, and connect.
That’s a lot of hoops to jump through. But it should work. Right? Yeah. I like this one.
Just one problem, though. I don’t have the guard’s login and password.
Eh. Cross that bridge when I get to it. Can’t spend the whole night scheming. Figure it out as I go.
Let’s say I use the phone to call network security, impersonate one of the staff, or better yet, a remote admin.
I come up with some contrived reason for why they should enable the intra-office RAIN, and boom—I’m in.
Who would be the best staffer to connect to? Some sort of low-level…
Wait… Is their network security staff on call 24 hours a day? Because it’s 4:00am right now.
Given the level of tech around here, I’d surprised if they even have a network security staff.
It’s probably, like, one guy with a ponytail and a pager.
Rats. I kinda wanted to try this one. Oh well.
Maybe there’s a nearby RAIN I could tap into, jump back onto the grids and figure out what’s going on.
But I’ve been scanning for any trace of RAIN since I started up the minicomputer. Not a blip.
There aren't really any universities or hotels around here. Likely no wireless to be found.
If I want RAIN, I’ll have to make it myself somehow.
I bet I could figure out a way to trick the guard into sharing his connection over RAIN.
Unless… Now that I think about it, he may not even have access to the outside world from that terminal. Wouldn’t surprise me, actually.
Too much of a risk. The guy may not be computer savvy, but he’s watching me like a hawk. He’ll catch on pretty quick if I try something shady.
Hey, while we wait for that print server to come back online, do you mind if I ask you a question?
Do I look like a cab driver?
I just—
Why are you such a dick?
So, pretty tight security around here, huh?
What’s your login and password?
Did you figure out how to get this garbage off my screen?
Uh right, just a sec.
I can’t just blurt out the password reset command. There must be a way to use the Nexus to conceal what I’m doing.
What is your problem? I’ve been nothing but polite and helpful since I got here, and all I’m getting from you is abuse.
That’s your idea of abuse? Trust me, kid. When I decide to get abusive, you’ll know.
My name’s Declan, by the way. In case you get tired of calling me “kid” all the time.
I don’t need to know your name. In a few hours, they’ll take you to processing and hopefully prison. Then maybe I’ll have some peace and quiet around here.
I hope they replace you with a robot.
I’m sure they’re working on it.
So, uh… what’s the security like around here? Looks pretty intense, from what I can see.
I suppose. Anyway, how do I get rid of this crap on my screen?
Huh? Oh, right, you’re still in the console.
Duh! I don’t have to guess this guy’s password at all. I can just reset it from the console.
Just need to get him to type “reset admin passwd * /default”.
Except… well. The guard may not be computer savvy, but I can’t imagine he’d fall for that one.
I’d better go root around the Nexus, find a clever way to send that reset command.
So, uh… when you log into your machine, like… do you, um…
How ‘bout you quit babbling and tell me how I get rid of this crap on my screen.
Crap on your—? Oh. You’re still in the console.
That’s it! I don’t have to do anything to figure out this guy’s password. I can just reset it directly from the console.
I just need to get him to type “reset admin passwd * /default”.
Except… yeah. The guard may not be computer savvy, but I can’t imagine he’d fall for that one.
I’d better go root around the Nexus, find a clever way to send that reset command.
Hmm. These hacking tools are all designed to connect directly to a server. They’re not really for scamming people conversationally. Unless…
The compiler runs locally—it’s more of an accessory tool, really. Lets me test out out small code fragments.
What if, instead of having the guard input a password-reset command directly, I had him type in a one-line program that generated that same command?
That’s so convoluted and impractical, it just might work!
Let’s do it!
Wait, not yet.
